Title: Home Alone
Review: Home Alone is one of the most iconic Christmas movies of all time. It's one that I heard about every year come holiday season. As such, I'm genuinely quite blown away by the fact that this was my first time seeing it. Certainly, I had seen some snippets here and there and knew what the movie was about, but for the most part, I saw it without knowing what would happen.  Since this was the first time for me seeing Home Alone, I'll start by saying that I absolutely adored it. It was tremendously entertaining, funny, and enjoyable. It felt wonderfully Christmasy and captured the essence of the holiday perfectly. While it's easy to focus on the chaotic antics of the third act, I also loved how important family was in this movie. Be it Kevin wishing he had his family back, or his mom doing anything in her power to get back to her son. Or, maybe even the neighbour connecting with his son again. In the midst of all the chaos and comedy, there is also a wonderful and heartwarming message in there. And although I really, really enjoyed all the action, this movie wouldn't be anywhere near as good as it is, if it weren't for that message.  The story, which I'm sure everyone is already more than familiar with, leaves us with Kevin, an eight-year-old boy accidentally left behind from the family trip to Paris. While Kevin, who isn't the biggest fan of his family, enjoys the freedom he has, he soon realizes how much he actually misses them. And when a pair of burglars try to take advantage of the parents being gone, Kevin must overcome his fears and defend the house. It's a story that sounds extremely simple on paper. And while for the most part, it is, the way it's crafted, leaves room for countless wonderful and iconic moments. It's genuinely fun to watch Kevin learn about the most ordinary everyday things, like laundry and grocery shopping, and it's equally fun to follow the chaotic journey that the rest of the family has. Once you add the cherry on the top, which is, of course, the third act battle between Kevin and the burglars, what you have, is an immensely entertaining film.  What surprised me the most, was how gruesome, and brutal, Kevin's traps were. In fact, the whole battle sequence was much darker than I ever could've expected. However, the way it's handled makes it an enormously funny sequence. Harry and Marv, the burglars, create most of the comedy in Home Alone, and they are fantastic. They provide funny scenes throughout the film but truly shine once they try to rob the McCallister house. No matter how brutally Kevin's traps harm them, their reactions are always hilarious and wonderfully over the top. Quite rarely do I find myself laughing out loud while watching a movie, but during Home Alone, I found myself doing it quite often. The comedy, which feels quite carefully administered, always feels natural and never unnecessarily forced. The result, accordingly, is wonderful.  Although it took me embarrassingly long to finally watch Home Alone, I'm glad I did. Before seeing it, I never understood why so many people spoke so highly of it. But now, it's easy to see why. It's a wonderful movie filled with Christmas cheer and a heartwarming story, while simultaneously being tremendously entertaining and funny. It's a film that just became a part of my Christmas tradition, and it's one that I absolutely love. 1 out of 1 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote. Permalink

Title: A wonderful holiday film by the late John Hughes
Review: If someone tells you to be careful what you wish for, you better take them seriously. After a tumultuous evening, Kevin McCallister (Macaulay Culkin) wishes he didn't have a family. Title: A Hughes-Columbus Christmas Classic
Review: After being accidentally left home alone by his family, Kevin McAllister (Macaulay Culkin) must defend his residence from the Wet Bandits (Daniel Stern and Joe Pesci), who are for some reason obsessed with the idea of hurting the little boy and stealing useless knick-knacks.  This film is a legend and a classic. Released in 1990, it captures both the more serious 1990s with the fun 1980s. Two 1980s masters come together to film this one: John Hughes as writer ("Sixteen Candles", "Pretty in Pink", "The Breakfast Club") and Chris Columbus as director ("Adventures in Babysitting"). This makes for the perfect blend in young adult situation comedy.  This is the film that launched Macaulay Culkin's career. While he had previously appeared in "Jacob's Ladder" and "Uncle Buck", this was (and remains) his biggest and most cherished role. I would find it safe to say no film since has really captured the essence of Macaulay. While "Saved" and "Party Monster" are both (possibly) equally as good movies, they do not have the mass appeal of "Home Alone".  What is best about the film is its sense of fun. The plot really makes little sense. How does a family not notice they have an extra plane ticket or that a sibling is missing? Why would burglars break into a house where they can be identified? How can Joe Pesci get beat up relentlessly and not curse once? Is it possible to not have a single friend, family member or neighbor in all of Chicago? The "Scream" joke was used too much (four times). At least one, and probably two, instances could have been removed. Do we need to see a little boy twice getting burned by aftershave? Of course not. The repeated use of the "keep the change you filthy animal" joke seemed to work very well, though, strangely enough.  Overall, this is a great Christmas movie. Along with "Die Hard" this is one you really need to make sure you watch around the holidays, at least once. If you have never seen "Home Alone" you are one of five people on earth or something... it was a huge success. With good reason. So see it. 1 out of 4 found this helpful. Was this review helpful?
